article.title: Photon-photon scattering at the high-intensity frontier

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 illustrates a three-dimensional laser beam collision setup. What do the arrows labeled e<sub>k1</sub>, e<sub>k2</sub>, and e<sub>k3</sub> represent?
choices: The polarization direction of the laser beams.
The electric field vectors of the laser beams.
The propagation directions of the laser beams.
The momentum vectors of the signal photons.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 depicts the directional emission characteristics of signal photons for a specific collision scenario. What key advantage for signal-to-background separation does this figure illustrate?
choices: The signal photons have a distinct polarization compared to the laser beams.
The signal photons are predominantly emitted outside the forward cones of the laser beams.
The signal photons exhibit a broader energy spectrum than the driving laser beams.
The signal photons are emitted with a specific time delay compared to the laser pulses.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (3) describes the zero-to-single signal photon transition amplitude. What approximation is essential for this formula to be valid?
choices: Plane-wave approximation for the laser beams.
Locally-constant-field approximation for the Heisenberg-Euler effective Lagrangian.
Neglection of higher-order loop corrections in the QED perturbative expansion.
Assumption of circular polarization for the high-intensity laser beams.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (6) relates the peak field strength E<sub>0,b</sub> of a laser beam to several beam parameters. According to this formula, how does the peak field strength change if the pulse duration τ is doubled, keeping all other parameters constant?
choices: The peak field strength remains unchanged.
The peak field strength is halved.
The peak field strength is reduced by a factor of √2.
